title: My mother died. Oldest sister is executrix. I'm estranged and want to know what is happening to house she paid off in full.
question: She may owe nursing home for care and board and city loan obtained to refurbish house and yards 15 years ago. She had a will that states all 5 children get equal shares of whatever there is to split. I am estranged and can't ask any of them. She died Jan. 25 2015. Sister has always told me the city was taking the house but my brother has been there cleaning up yards. Why would he do that if it was going to be taken from us. It doesn't make any sense. I would like to know and stop stressing over it as I am a Stroke Survivor and not supposed to be under any stress!
answers:
Probate would be started in the county your mother lived in. Check the court records there.
As others have said, if no probate is started, wait about 60 days, then start the probate with you as Administrator and your mother as intestate. With the filing fee and the cost to publish notice in the local paper of general circulation (usually the one that shows up that you do not pay for), you will be out of pocket between $750 and $1000.
If probate has been started, prepare and file a Request for Special Notice (form DE 154) so that you are mailed a copy of everything filed with the court. There is a fee to file this. It is currently $40.

The city does not want the home, they want their money back. They should work with the estate to do that.

First look to see if a Petition for Probate has been filed. If not, wait 30-60 days and if one is not filed, file your own. Be careful about your timing and don't allow this to cause you stress. It has not been that long, and things may very well take their course without incident so you might want to give it a chance for that to happen.

You have a legal right to see a copy of any will or trust. You also have a right to get notices of any estate administration. If the estate is being administered under a trust, then you have a right to a full accounting of the estates assets and debts. If you are being ignored or rebuffed, then you cant get court orders on these disclosures. You might need to seek the services of a skilled probate attorney.

My condolences on the loss of your mother. You should check the Probate court in the county in which your mom lived to see if there has been a probate filed. You may also want to write a letter to your sister asking that she provide you with a copy of the Will and to keep you informed about the status of your mother's estate.

You can check with the County Recorder's office in the county where the property resides to find out who is on title and whether there are any liens against it. That will give you a sense of whether anything will be left in your mom's estate.

If you hear nothing, allow at least 60 days to pass, seek a copy of your mom's death certificate and file Petition for Probate using the services of an experienced Probate attorney.

I highly recommend you CONSULT with an attorney to explore your options and understand the process BEFORE you file anything as there are expenses involved.

If your sister will not give you a copy of the will you can file a petition to probate your mother's estate as if she had no will (intestate) that will force her to produce the will or you will be able to take over the estate. You can also check the records of the county recorder to find out who is in title to the house and whether there are any liens against it. You might want to contact the San Bernardino County Bar Association Layer Referral Service they can probably recommend a lawyer to give you some assistance.
